newsitem.title: kuwait: Kuwait crown prince condition "good" in hospital.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait crown prince condition "good" in hospital.

text.p: Kuwaiti Crown Prince and Prime Minister Sheikh Saad al-Abdulla al-Sabah was taken to hospital on Tuesday for medical tests following a sudden health problem.
"Thank God he is in good condition," said an official who accompanied Sheikh Saad to hospital. He refused to elaborate.
It was not immediately clear what Sheikh Saad, born in 1930, was suffering from but one Western diplomatic source said there were indications he was in good condition.

Sheikh Saad was at the airport on Monday with Kuwait's Emir Sheikh Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah to receive Congo's President Pascal Lissouba. Sheikh Saad, prime minister and crown prince since 1978, later visited Lissouba at his residence.
"I heard it could be general fatigue," said a senior Kuwaiti oil industry executive. "I think he is now resting at hospital."
Kuwait, a founder of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, produces about two million barrels of oil per day. It controls 10 percent of the world's proven oil reserves.

The emiri court earlier on Tuesday issued a statement on the official Kuwaiti news agency (KUNA) telling citizens that Sheikh Saad's condition was "extremely reassuring" after suffering a "sudden indisposition".
Sheikh Saad, educated in Kuwait and at Britain's Hendon Police Training School, has steered the government through turbulent times at home and abroad.

He started his career with Kuwait's police in 1945, becoming chief of police and public security in 1961. He held the defence and interior portifolios until a year before the 1979 Islamic revolution in non-Arab Iran across the narrow Gulf.
Hours after Iraqi troops crossed the border into Kuwait on August 2, 1990, Sheikh Saad vowed in a broadcast from a secret location to fight "until we clean their (Iraqi) treachery from our land".

Seven years after the U.S.-led military coalition defeated Iraq in the 1991 Gulf War and freed Kuwait from a seven-month Iraqi occupation, Sheikh Saad is strongly opposed to even consider offers to hold direct contacts with Baghdad.
